conclusion: To determine which blocks A will collide with and where it will eventually stop, we need to consider the following factors: Initial Direction and Speed, Collision and Deflection, Block Arrangement.
Initial Direction and Speed: A is moving from the right towards the group of blocks. The speed and direction will influence the collision and deflection.
Collision and Deflection: When A collides with a block, it will transfer some of its momentum. The angle and speed of A will determine how it deflects after each collision.
Block Arrangement: The arrangement of the blocks will affect the path A takes after each collision.
In the initial scene, there are many blocks of different colors placed and A has not yet entered.

conclusion: A is likely to collide with the first block it encounters, which is the orange block closest to its path.

conclusion: After colliding with the red square, A continued to move forward and collided with the green square.

premise: A will continue to collide with blocks, transferring momentum and changing direction each time.
conclusion: A will eventually stop after losing enough momentum from multiple collisions.
